summary:
Biomedical engineer with expertise in computational biology and a strong background in epidemiological research. I am experienced in utilizing data mining and machine learning algorithms to uncover patterns in complex biological datasets, facilitating the identification of cardiovascular biomarkers. 
Currently working toward a PhD degree in the groups of Molecular Epidemiolgy in the LUMC. Supervised by Prof. Dr. Eline Slagboom (LUMC), Prof Dr. Marcel Reinders (TU Delft), and Ir. Dr. Erik van den Akker (LUMC) I used with large population studies (e.g. BBMRI-nl) to identify cardiovascular and aging biomarkers. Combining advanced algorithms with different -omics levels (e.g. metabolomics and DNA methylation) I trained and analyzed several risk models for cardiovascular risk factors. 
I also created and maintained  for 2 years a Rshiny package named MiMIR (available on CRAN: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/MiMIR/index.html) to apply our metabolomics models to other studies.
I was also a member of the board of the LUMC PhD Association for 2 years, in which I organized several events. I am open-minded, autonomous and respectful. Always keen on learning new skills and collaborating with people from all over the world.

projects.title: Sleep Stage Classi fication using Unsupervised Feature Learning
projects.description:
Our aim was to fi nd a method which is able to classify wake, rapid-eye movement (REM)
sleep and non-REM (NREM) light and deep sleep, by analyzing sleep patterns from ECG and respiratory signals on a 30 s epoch basis.
Sleep constitutes approximately one third of our lives and has a big impact on health  and  well-being.  Sleep  monitoring  can  aid  in  the  diagnosis  of  a  variety of  sleep  and  psychiatric  disorders. 
In this  work we  proposed a variety  of  Neural  Network architectures  able  to classify sleep stages in an Unsupervised way. We implemented a DBN-LSTM architecture, an LSTM and a CNN. We compared the results from all of them and also with a Supervised Neural Network that used feature previously revealed by clinicians.

projects.title: Gene expression analysis of RNA sequencing data of patients affected by kidney renal clear cell carcinoma
projects.description:
This project had the aim to do a gene expression analysis of the RNA Sequencing data estracted from 71 patients affected by kidney renal clear cell carcinoma (KIRC). The data was downloaded from the TCGA database during December 2014, and it contained the data from the normal cells, the cancerous cells for all the 71 patients. Moreover, also the microRNA expression from was available.
Therefore, we analyzed the gene expression data using a t-test and a Fold Change analysis to reveal the genes that changed more their expression between the normal condition and the cancerous condition. The same analysis was done for both theRNAs and the microRNAs, obtaining two lists. In order to do this, I created a MATLAB GUI.
Subsequently, we analyzed if the differentially expressed genes were functionally enriched in Biological Process, Molecular Functions or Cellular Components terms, using the web tool Fidea. This revealed some interesting properties of the cancer. Finally, I analyzed the most interesting RNAs and microRNAs differentially expressed, looking also if they were previously related to the disease in previous studies.

projects.title: Discovery of the gene regulated by the cell cycle
projects.description:
This project aimed to reveal the genes that are regulated in the cell cycle, using the method proposed by by De Lichtemberg et al ( at DOI: 10.1093/bioinformatics/bti093) as benchmark. In a really interactive class we were abe to discuss and create new methods to select better these genes. 
In particular my project used the cross correlation to find similarities between the expression of the cyclins and the one of the other genes. Indeed, cycins is a family of proteins that control the progression of cells through the cell cycle, so they could be useful to individuate other possible regulatory genes.

projects.title: Quality control of a medical ultrasound device
projects.description: We performed a quality control of a medical ultrasound device (ESAOTE Technos MPX) that was available inside the campus, using a quantitative analysis of the images. We checked the resolution, the gain, the depth, etc. In order to do this we used also a material to simulate a patient with a cyst (CIRS model 54).
